Predominately in calcareous situations that are often seasonally wet. Quite weedy in places. These populations may represent Eurasian introductions.

Successional fields, pastures, wet thickets, wet disturbed soils, edges of dirt roads, and marshes.  Generally grows in non-shaded habitats with wet soils but sometimes occurs in more mesic soils. Populations are often small in number and individual plants are widely spaced.
Various types of forests but particularly floodplain and successional forests, forest edges, openings in forests, thickets, and disturbed sites.
Hardwood forests (often of a southern affinity) and forest edges in mesic to dry-mesic predominately thin soils.

Successional fields, pastures, wet thickets, wet disturbed soils, edges of dirt roads, and marshes Generally grows in non-shaded habitats with wet soils but sometimes occurs in more mesic soils. Populations are often small in number and individual plants are widely spaced.
Seeps in cool hardwood and mixed hardwood-coniferous forests and openings in swamps.
Rich fens, swamps, and wet thickets. A calciphile at least in the warmer and more southern parts of New York.
Swamps and vernal pools in shallow still standing water.
Marshes, edges of ponds, and swamps. Predominately in saturated to slightly inundated soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Glyceria grandis S. Watson var. grandis
Habitat: Marshes, openings in swamps, and wet thickets. In saturated to slightly inundated soils.
Swamps and swamp openings, seeps in forests, and wet thickets. Predominately growing in shaded to partly shaded habitats with saturated but not inundated soils.

Edges of small streams, seeps in forests, swamps, damp dirt roads through forests, wet thickets, and occasionally marshes. A very common species that often occur in shaded habitats that have at least seasonally wet soils.
Dry-mesic to mesic forests often on thin acidic soils with some pine or hemlock. The adjacent herbaceous vegetation is often sparse.
Coniferous, mixed hardwood-coniferous, and hardwood forests predominately in thin acidic soils.
Coniferous, mixed hardwood-coniferous, and hardwood forests predominately in thin acidic soils.

Exposed mud flats along the edges of streams, ponds, and lakes; brackish tidal marshes, pastures, and disturbed soils. A plant predominately of wet-mesic to periodically flooded soils with the adjacent herbaceous vegetation sparse.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Greeneochloa coarctata (Eaton) P.M. Peterson, Soreng, Romasch. & Barberá

Habitat: Cool hardwood, coniferous, and mixed hardwood-coniferous forests. Also hummocks in swamps and edges of streams. More common in the northern and cooler parts of New York.

Floodplain forests, alluvial thickets, disturbed forests, and thickets. Mostly a species of deep alluvial soils and often under a tree canopy. The fruits are among the toughest of our native species to remove from clothing once attached.
An understory shrub in various dry-mesic to mesic hardwood forests.
Rocky summits, bluffs, disturbed soils in forests, logging roads, and dirt road sides.
Tidal wetlands, marshes, fens, stream banks, and gravel bars in streams. This species does particularly well in the fresh tidal marshes of the Hudson.

Most common on stream banks and in alluvial thickets and forests.  It also occurs in deciduous swamps, wet forests, and wet to mesic disturbed areas. This species is long rhizomatous and can create large dense patches.

Dry to dry-mesic deciduous forests, thin forests, and woodlands as well as edges of these habitats. This species does best on dry rocky thinly forested slopes where the herbaceous vegetation is not very tall or dense but can be quite diverse. It can form large patches although it usually does not grow in dense stands.
Alluvial thickets and forests, stream banks, and disturbed areas in alluvial soils. Predominately a species of alluvial soils.
Rich mesic forests often on lower slopes and bottoms of valleys in deep soils. When co-occurring with Hepatica americana it often occurs lower on slopes in deeper moister soils.
Dry-mesic to mesic forests and forest edges in alkaline to circumneutral soils. When co-occurring with Hepatica acutiloba it often occurs higher on slopes in shallower drier soils.
Stream banks, rich seepy forests, occasionally roadside ditches, and wet meadows.  Perhaps more common in suitable habitat in the northern part of the state.
Ponds, lakes, and streams in alkaline to circumneutral water. Sometimes the plants become stranded on gravel/sand bars in streams and edges of streams, ponds, and lakes.

Rock outcrops in hardwood forests, hardwood forests of a southern affinity, and forest openings. Generally associated with rock outcrops but sometimes found simply in forested situations. A species of the warmer and more southern parts of New York.
Road side clearings, disturbed areas, thin forests, and edges of forests.
Deciduous, often thin, forests and edges of forests on dry to mesic slopes. The adjacent herbaceous vegetation is usually not dense or tall.
Edges of deciduous forests, thin forests, woodlands, road banks, utility line clearings, and successional fields with thin soils. Does not do well with intensive herbaceous competition.

Dry-mesic to dry thin forests to woodlands often on slopes. Sometimes it occurs on the edges of forests or woodlands but it is really more of an understory plant. The adjacent herbaceous vegetation is often low and not dense.

Rich hardwood forests, bottomland forests, and shale and fine talus slopes. A calciphile of the richest soils. Somewhat local in distribution but also occurring in large stands. Often occurs where the adjacent vegetation is diverse and rich.

Dry-mesic to mesic open forests and woodlands, dirt roads through forests, forest edges, fields with thin herbaceous vegetation, roadsides, lawns, disturbed soils, and open exposed bedrock often in thin dry soils but sometimes in wet sites.
Dry forest openings and bluffs in thin rocky soils sometimes on calcareous soils and bedrock.
Cool mesic northern hardwood, coniferous, and hardwood-coniferous forests. Most common on hilltops and in more northern and cooler parts of New York.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Huperzia lucidula × H. porophila = H. ×bartleyi (Cusick) Kartesz & Gandhi
Huperzia selago (L.) Bernh. ex Schrank & Mart.

Habitat: Marshes, swamps, stream banks, and wet ditches usually where the herbaceous vegetation is not dense or tall. This species likes exposed saturated or wet soils. It also does well over mosses in wet areas.
Rich often at least somewhat calcareous mesic hardwood forests. Often with a dense and diverse adjacent herbaceous layer.
Mesic hardwood forests, bottomland forests on deep alluvium, edges of forests, and thickets. Sometimes somewhat weedy although not able to out-compete various non-native invasive herbs.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Hylodesmum glutinosum (Muhl. ex Willd.) H. Ohashi & R.R. Mill
Species_Author: (Muhl. ex Willd.) H. Ohashi & R.R. Mill
Habitat: Dry-mesic to mesic, slightly rich, hardwood forests. Often on mid to upper slopes. Usually never too abundant at a site but it is one of the most widespread Desmodium species in New York.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Hylodesmum nudiflorum (L.) H. Ohashi & R.R. Mill
Habitat: Dry-mesic to mesic forests and woodlands. In acidic soils on upper slopes as well as richer deeper soils. One of the most common Desmodium species in New York.
Various wetlands without trees or shrubs and usually without adjacent tall and dense herbaceous vegetation. Springy edges of wetlands including springy roadsides
Marshes, shrub swamps, and acidic peaty wetlands.

Rocky summits, rock outcrops, and open habitats with very thin soils. Often in cracks in rocks or where small amounts of soil has formed. Usually in vernally wet areas that dry out later in the season.

One of the most common wetland Hypericum species in New York. Marshes, stream edges, and pond edges.  Does particularly well on open mud flats on draw down zones of ponds, marshes, streams, and drainage channels.
Woods roads, forests, and edges of fields. At least in parts of New York it grows in slightly mineral rich dry-mesic forests with thin but diverse and interesting herbaceous vegetation.
Marshes, shrub swamps, and acidic peaty wetlands.
In a wide variety of dry-mesic to mesic forests. Often not occurring in large populations and much less frequent then the more common M. uniflora.
Oak dominated forests, woodlands, rocky summits, and utility rights-of-way in dry to dry-mesic soils. Most common in warmer and more southern parts of New York.
Swamps with trees and/or shrubs dominant.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Ilex montana Torr. & A. Gray ex A. Gray
Species_Author: Torr. & A. Gray ex A. Gray

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Ilex mucronata (L.) M. Powell, Savol & S. Andrews
Habitat: Various types of acidic peat bogs, deciduous swamps, mixed coniferous-deciduous swamps, and shrub swamps.  Mostly this species does not form dense thickets but occurs scattered in with a variety of other shrubs.  Sometimes it can be dwarfed when in hostile bog conditions. It is more common in the northern parts of the state.
Margins of ponds, kettle hole ponds, acidic bogs, deciduous swamps, and shrub swamps (sometimes being the dominant shrub).  In most of NY this is our most common wetland Ilex.

Floodplain forests, wet forests, seepage areas, swamps, marshes, fens, stream banks, thickets, disturbed areas, shaded roadsides and trail edges, and ditches. A very common annual of wet to mesic soils, preferring wetter sites. It can form dense large stands.

Floodplain forests, wet forests, seepage areas, swamps, marshes, fens, stream banks, thickets, disturbed areas, shaded roadsides and trail edges, and ditches. Similar habitat to I. capensis and sometimes occurring together but not as common in at least parts of NY. It perhaps prefers more calcareous soils. Like I. capensis it can form dense large patches.

Rocky summits, woodlands, ledges, roadside clearings where it is not too weedy, and utility line rights-of-way, on thin and/or sandy soil or almost directly on bedrock. This species does well with a lot of light but not with dense herbaceous vegetation.
Swamps, shrub swamps, marshes, rich fens, and acidic bogs. Grows in a wide variety of wetland types.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Isoetes echinospora × I. engelmannii = I. ×eatonii R. Dodge
Isoetes echinospora × I. septentrionalis = I. ×robusta (Engelm.) D.F.Brunt.
Isoetes echinospora Durieu ssp. muricata (Durieu) Á. Löve & D. Löve
Habitat: Submerged and rooted aquatic on the edges of lakes often in sandy or coarse soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Isoetes tuckermanii A. Braun ex Engelm.
Habitat: Edges of often acidic lakes.

In certain parts of its range in New York, it is primarily associated with talus slopes. Elsewhere in New York, it is associated with rich mesic hardwood forests on valley bottoms and lower slopes sometimes on calcareous bedrock and soils. Often it occurs in small patches of only a few trees. Butternut canker is killing this species and it is difficult to find individuals that are not infected.

Cultivated and apparently native. Native Americans may have been responsible for bringing this tree to parts of New York. Floodplain forests, low and rich mesic hardwood forests, and successional forests. Also, often found in large patches near old home sites. Does best in deep alluvial soils where it can become a dominant tree. It is also somewhat weedy and once established sometimes creates monospecific stands.
Marshes, wet depressions, emergent on edges of ponds and lakes, edges of streams, and ditches. Occurs in a wide variety of wet to at least seasonally wet mostly open habitats.
Marshes, edges of swamps, wet ditches, shores of streams and ponds, and rich fens. Occurs in a wide variety of wet mostly open habitats.
Edges of streams, wet ditches, marshes, and various other wet to seasonally wet habitats.

Dirt and logging roads, and shores of streams, ponds, and lakes in seasonally wet to wet-mesic exposed soils. An annual which appears to need exposed soils probably for germination. Adjacent herbaceous vegetation is usually sparse and not tall.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Juncus canadensis J. Gay ex Laharpe
Habitat: Marshes, edges of ponds and lakes, fens, and various other wetlands. Often emergent from standing water. One of the later species of Juncus to flower and fruit.

Rich fens, calcareous marshes, gravel pits, and at least seasonally wet to wet-mesic fields, ditches, and other mostly open calcareous habitats. Predominately restricted to at least slightly calcareous soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Juncus effusus L. ssp. solutus (Fernald & Wiegand) Hämet-Ahti
Habitat: Edges of ponds and streams, wet fields, marshes, openings in swamps, ditches, and swales. Occurs in a wide variety of open wet to seasonally wet habitats. Habitat differences between var. pylaei and var. solutus are not clear.
Coastal and inland salt marshes, and becoming fairly common on edges of major roads where salt is applied.
Marshes, ditches, edges of swamps, and wet fields. Occurs in a wide variety of wet to at least seasonally wet-mesic soils in open habitats.
Marshes, shores and banks of streams and ponds including ice scoured shores, openings in swamps, rich fens, and ditches. Widespread in a wide variety of open wetlands.
Sandy or peaty shores of lakes and streams, and rich fens.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Juncus secundus P. Beauv. ex Poir.
Habitat: Rocky summits and open dry exposed graminoid dominated hill tops in acidic soils.
Marshes, edges of streams, and peaty acidic and basic wetlands including fens. In a wide variety of wet habitats and perhaps overlooked.
Paths, roadsides, and fields. Very common in heavily compacted wet to dry soils of paths.
Marshes, edges of ponds, and other wetland habitats. Somewhat local in distribution but often occurring in large populations.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Juniperus communis L. var. depressa Pursh
Habitat: Rocky summits, dry woodlands and forests, edges of forests, and bluffs.

Rocky summits, bluffs above ravines and lakes, ledges, alvars, successional fields, pastures, and maritime and coastal sandy areas. Grows best in open sites with thin rocky or sandy dry soils and dies back if other trees shade it out. In parts of New York, it is associated with calcareous bedrock or soils and in general is somewhat of a calciphile.
Sub-alpine forests, wet acidic peatlands, and dry sandy forests and forest edges. Primarily a species of acidic soils it grows in dry to wet open or slightly shaded habitats.

Oak dominated mesic to dry forests, woodlands, rocky summits, utility rights-of-way, and occasionally acidic swamps. Primarily a species of dry Quercus montana dominated forests often in association with other ericaceous shrubs. It sometimes forms dense thickets. Very limited in central and western New York but quite common in the southeastern parts of the state.
Acidic bogs. Often grows mixed with other shrubs.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Koeleria spicata (L.) Barberá, Quintanar, Soreng & P.M. Peterson
Habitat: Rock outcrops often associated with or near rivers. Often in high pH sites.
Mesic young forests.
Dry to dry-mesic rocky summits, burned forests, woodlands, disturbed soils, and fields with thin soils.
Cut forests, edges and clearings in forests, roadsides, thickets, maritime dunes, and disturbed areas.
Cut forests, edges and clearings in forests, roadsides, thickets, edges of fields, and disturbed areas.
Rich wet-mesic to mesic forests, stream edges, and forested seeps. Generally in rich cool shaded wet-mesic sites and sometimes forming large dense populations.

Bogs, cool northern swamps, rich peatlands, and cool mesic forests at high elevation. Predominately a plant of cool northern wetlands it is local in distribution in the warmer and more southern parts of New York.
Marshes and wet thickets. Can occur in inland salt marshes.
Woodlands, pine barrens, rocky summits, utility rights-of-way, fields, and gravel pits. Mostly in acidic thin soils.
Utility rights-of-way and other open habitats in thin soils.
Marshes, swamps, and low wet thickets. Growing in wetter often more open sites than the related Leersia virginica.
Edges of dirt roads through forests, seepages in forests, and wet thickets. Predominately in seasonal wet to damp shaded sites.
Quiet water of lakes, ponds, vernal pools, marshes, and channels. Sometimes becoming temporarily stranded.
Quiet water of ponds, lakes, and marshes.
Roadsides, fields, and disturbed areas. In dry soils.
Pine barrens, woodlands, dry fields, edges of forests, railroad edges, and utility rights-of-way. In dry to dry-mesic acidic sandy or coarse soils. Less common in central and western New York.
Dry to dry-mesic woodlands, rocky summits, and edges of forests.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Lespedeza hirta × L. violacea = L. ×nuttallii Darl.

Habitat: Woodlands, dry fields, thin forests, clearings in forests, railroad edges, and utility rights-of-way. Similar habitat to L. capitata but perhaps sometimes in slightly more shaded sites.
Dry-mesic to mesic hardwood forests, woodlands, barrens, bluffs, and rocky summits.
Dry to mesic acid hardwood forests, woodlands, rocky summits, thickets, and gravelly dirt road sides.
Dry-mesic hardwood forests and woodlands. Often on rocky acidic to circumneutral soils including shale talus on upper slopes and bluffs.
Dry to dry-mesic woodlands, rocky summits, and edges of forests.

Alluvial thickets, floodplain forests, and wet thickets. Usually flowering best in non-shaded sites. Often in peaty or wet springy soils. Perhaps in more acidic soils than ssp. editorum. More work is needed to asses the habitat differences of the two ssp.
Forests, woodlands, edges of forests, and utility rights-of-way in dry thin or sandy soils. Often on hilltops in partial shade in relatively poor soils.
Sand dunes and other sandy non-shaded habitats in maritime areas, dry exposed rocky outcrops and summits, bluffs, roadsides, and disturbed sites.

Floodplain forests, swamps, shrub swamps, wet woods, mesic forests, seeps in forests, and fens. Occurs in mesic to wet soils often but not always in at least partial shade. In some forest understories it can be the dominant species in the shrub layer.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Lindernia dubia (L.) Pennell var. anagallidea (Michx.) Cooperr.

Habitat: Exposed soils of the draw down zones of the edges of rivers, streams, ponds, and lakes including brackish to fresh intertidal estuaries in gravelly to muddy saturated to wet-mesic soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Linnaea borealis L. ssp. longiflora (Torr.) Piper & Beattie
Habitat: Hummocks in cool swamps; on mosses in thin soils and decaying logs; cool coniferous to mixed coniferous-deciduous forests; and roadsides. Linnaea borealis grows in both unshaded and shaded habitats as well as dry to wet sites. It is a more northern plant that is more common in the northern and cooler parts of NY and is more restricted in distribution in the warmer parts of the state.
Openings in forests, edges of forests, and dirt roads through forests on non-weedy roadsides on dry to dry-mesic thin soils.

Common_Name: tulip tree, tulip poplar, yellow poplar
Habitat: Mesic to wet-mesic hardwood forests. In all but the most southern parts of New York this tree is often an indicator of deep rich mesic circumneutral soils growing primarily in valley bottoms (excluding the lowest floodplains) and on lower slopes. In the most southern parts of the state it also grows in more acidic drier sites and occurs in a wider array of forested habitats.

Marshes, swamps, wet thickets, gravely stream banks, margins of drainages, edges of ponds including marl ponds, and wet ledges. Occurs in both shaded and unshaded sites almost always in saturated to wet-mesic soils.
Soft water lakes and ponds. Basal rosette of leaves are submersed and grow on firm sandy to gravelly (occasionally more mucky) substrates. Scapes are submersed or often become emersed.

Dirt and logging roads; cut forests, forest clearings, and thin forests; and gravel bars of streams and disturbed areas. Often along paths, on tip up mounds, or other disturbed soils in mesic to dry-mesic forested sites. Occasionally in drier sites.

Wet calcareous cliffs; gravelly and peaty banks of streams and ponds; and fens and other calcareous wet sites. Lobelia kalmii is a small plant and it grows best where the adjacent herbaceous vegetation is low. It grows almost exclusively in calcareous wet sites.
Seepage areas, stream margins, fens, ditches, and drainage channels; wet thickets and forests; swamps and seepy road banks. Does particularly well in calcareous seepage areas.
Wet to mesic fields and thickets; and disturbed soils.
Cool forests, forested or cool stream banks, and ledges. More common in cooler parts of NY as a general understory shrub in forests. In warmer parts of NY, it is more restricted to cooler sites.
Rocky thin forested slopes, forest edges, talus slopes, ledges, and thickets. A thin rather small vine becoming more robust in full sun.

Edges of ponds, lakes, and streams; wet depressions, vernal pools, swamps, and marshes. Grows predominately in open sites where the soils are saturated to seasonally inundated and the adjacent herbaceous vegetation is not dense or tall. It does particularly well in open exposed muddy edges that result from water levels dropping. It can form dense extensive patches.

Pine barrens, sandy open barrens, acidic oak dominated forests, bluffs, roadsides through forests, and edges of forests. This species does well with a relatively frequent fire regime. It may be decreasing in abundance as fires are prevented. In forested habitats, it often grows where Quercus montana and ericaceous shrubs are dominant.
Mesic forests and edges of forests.
Mesic forests, pastures, hayfields, and successional fields.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Luzula parviflora (Ehrh.) Desv. ssp. melanocarpa (Michx.) Hämet-Ahti
Habitat: Banks of streams and cool wet-mesic hardwood-coniferous or coniferous forests. Mostly restricted to cool northern forests in the more northern and/or cooler parts of New York.
Bogs, edges of ponds, and logging and dirt roads often on mosses or in peaty, sandy, or coarse soils. The most common Lycopodiella in New York.

Dry to mesic forests, forest openings, forest edges, and sometimes in more open sites in thin acidic soils. Also occasionally in mosses on edges of swamps and marshes. Does well in successional forests and in disturbed soils that become colonized by mosses.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Lycopodium lagopus (Laest. ex C. Hartm.) G. Zinserl. ex Kuzen.
Species_Author: (Laest. ex C. Hartm.) G. Zinserl. ex Kuzen.
Habitat: Edges of forests, sterile fields, ski slopes, and other dry to mesic open sterile sites. Sometimes occurring with L. clavatum.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Lycopus americanus Muhl. ex W.P.C. Barton
Habitat: Marshes, swamps, and edges of ponds and streams. Common in a large variety of wetlands.
Marshes, swamps, damp shores, ditches, and elsewhere. Common in a large variety of wetlands.
Mesic to wet acidic forests, forest edges, Sphagnum dominated peatlands, and swamps. Quite sparse in western and central New York.
Cool northern hardwood and mixed hardwood-coniferous forests. Also in peatlands. Often in acidic soils.
Fens, swamps, marshes, ditches, and wet thickets.
Acidic dry-mesic to mesic hardwood forests and forest edges. Sometimes it grows in more open sites but generally it is a forest herb.
Marshes, peatlands, ponds, lakes, slow moving stream edges, and ditches in shallow water or occasionally on only saturated soils.
Marshes and swamps often in relatively small populations that are not dense. Plants sometimes grow with dense herbaceous cover.
Mesic forests sometimes in deep rich and/or calcareous soils. Occasionally in dry-mesic or wet-mesic soils. It often occurs sparsely distributed and does not become a dominant tree in New York.
Mesic hardwood, coniferous, and hardwood-coniferous forests; and hummocks in swamps. It does particularly well in cool northern forests where it can be the dominant herbaceous plant.
Mesic hardwood and hardwood-coniferous forests. Widespread and common in a variety of forest types but perhaps absent from the drier most acidic sites.
Alluvial forests, mesic to wet forests, edges of marly ponds, and fens. Somewhat local in parts of New York. Perhaps preferring calcareous or deep rich wet-mesic or seasonally wet soils.
Wet peaty acidic soils. Bogs and wet springy forests in cool sites.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Matteuccia struthiopteris (L.) Tod. var. pensylvanica (Willd.) C.V. Morton
Habitat: Primarily a species of floodplain forests. Also, shores of streams, rich mesic forests, and less frequently swamps.
Mesic to wet-mesic hardwood, coniferous, and hardwood-coniferous forests. Occurs primarily in cool northern forests.
Floodplain forests and thickets, and rich forests over calcareous soils or bedrock. Most abundant on valley bottoms and lower slopes.
Marshes, wet thickets, and stream banks. Often grows in somewhat weedy thickets.
Bogs, poor to rich fens, rich swamps, and cool springy forests. Often in inundated soils and sometimes at the edge of ponds or streams in the habitats mentioned.
Floodplain and bottomland forests and thickets, low rich forests, and stream banks. Also cultivated.
Low areas in swamps and wet forests with mucky saturated soils.
Wet to mesic to seasonally dry rock outcrops and ledges; and thin soils on bluffs and in forest openings. Generally associated with rocks and often in areas that are at least seasonally seepy.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Milium effusum L. var. cisatlanticum Fernald
Habitat: Rich cool northern hardwood forests often in calcareous soils.
Fresh to brackish shores of rivers and streams; floodplain forests and thickets.
Marshes, wet thickets, ditches, edges of streams, pond and lake margins, and gravel and sand bars in streams. Predominately in non-shaded habitats.
Tsuga canadensis dominated forests with sparse herbaceous vegetation; other mesic forest types; and coastal oak forests in dry-mesic to mesic sandy soils.
Rich mesic forests, forested seeps, edges of swamps, and sometimes on hummocks in swamps. Generally in shaded habitats in deep rich soils of valley bottoms or lower slopes.
Mesic to low wet forests, wet to mesic thickets, edges of small intermittent drainages, and open peaty wet areas.
Forested seeps, stream banks, alluvial forests, and wet thickets.
Thickets, successional fields, edges and openings in hardwood forests, bluffs, and roadsides. Mostly in dry to dry-mesic soils in open habitats.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Monarda fistulosa L. var. mollis (L.) Benth.

Habitat: Highly localized in NY, it occurs on rocky summits and openings; and ledges in open (non-shaded) areas. The soils are acidic and thin. The adjacent herbaceous vegetation is minimal. It does well in seasonally wet areas in these habitats.
Thin coarse soil or in cracks of acidic rock on open rocky alpine and sub-alpine areas. Sometimes forming large masses in the appropriate habitat.
In a wide variety of dry-mesic to mesic forests. New plants appear in mid-summer.
This species is found in a few, apparently very different, habitat types including upland maritime habitats, dunes, rich open to forested fens, and open habitats in sandy or thin acidic soils.
Fairly local and populations are often small. Rich dry to dry-mesic forests often on calcareous bedrock or soils. Not weedy like M. alba.
Rich and medium fens, calcareous forested seeps, and occasionally in calcareous swamps.

Disturbed sites, alluvial thickets, utility rights-of-way, edges of streams, and thin forests. This species can occur in a wide range of habitats and can occur in dry to wet soils. It primarily appears to be associated with disturbed sites of various sizes and populations are usually not very large.
Lawns, various types of fields, roadsides, trails and dirt roads through forests, and disturbed sites.
Dry-mesic forested sites of a southern affinity often in rocky soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Muhlenbergia sylvatica (Torr.) Torr. ex A. Gray

Habitat: Dry-mesic forested sites of a southern affinity and openings in forests often in rocky soils.

Stream banks, wet thickets, seepage areas, and swamps. Our only native wetland Myosotis it has similar habitat preferences to M. scorpioides but usually is much less common and usually does not form as dense patches as that species.
Dry thin forests, woodlands, rocky summits, rock outcrops, bluffs, and shale talus slopes in dry, thin, and disturbed soils.
Edges of streams and ponds, shrub swamps, bogs, and fens. Mostly in cool peaty wet habitats. Sometimes becoming a dominant shrub species in these habitats.

Common_Name: various-leaved water milfoil, variable-leaved water milfoil
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, and quiet water of streams. Sometimes quite abundant.

Common_Name: woolly lip fern, hairy lip fern

Habitat: Forested slopes, forest edges, edges of paths and roads in forests, thickets, and talus. Often growing and doing best in calcareous soils.
Mesic forests, thickets, and edges of forests. Prenanthes altissima is a generalist in terms of soil preferences and is our most widespread and common Prenanthes throughout the state.
Forests, forests edges, and thickets. Growing into the alpine zone of New York's highest peaks.
Quiet water of ponds, streams, fresh to slightly brackish tidal rivers, and lake edges.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Najas gracillima (A. Braun ex Engelm.) Magnus

Habitat: Cool peaty swamps.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Nuphar advena (Aiton) W.T. Aiton ssp. advena
Common_Name: intertidal yellow pond lily, intertidal spatter dock
Habitat: In New York, it is predominately a species of the fresh and brackish tidal marshes along the Hudson River but also occurs in ponds and edges of lakes. Populations in artificially created wetlands may represent introductions.

Common_Name: small-leaved yellow pond lily, small-leaved spatter dock
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, and slow moving water of rivers.

Common_Name: common yellow pond lily, common spatter dock
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, and slow moving water of streams.
Lakes, ponds, and slow moving water of streams.

Swamps, wet depressions, wet woods, and borders of ponds and streams. Also in dry upland sites. Sometimes these upland sites are associated with seasonal springs or seeps. In the upland sites, populations are sometimes very small.
Cool mesic deciduous and mixed coniferous-deciduous forests and hummocks in swamps. Occurs where the soils are medium rich and the herbaceous layer is not dense.
Fields, pastures, thickets, gravel and sand bars in streams, roadsides, and disturbed soils. A native species of disturbed sites.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Oenothera fruticosa L. ssp. tetragona (Roth) W.L. Wagner

Habitat: Fields, edges of forests, and roadsides mostly in thin soils.

Wet forests, swamps, seepage areas, marshes, and wet fields. A somewhat weedy species that grows in a wide variety of at least seasonally wet habitats. In the northern and cooler parts of New York it is perhaps a little more restricted to rich seepage areas.
Springy open wet habitats including wet fields, banks of streams, and wet open road banks. Not a weedy species but growing in open habitats that sometimes have experienced past disturbances.

Rocky summits and outcrops, woodlands, sandy maritime areas, and sandy thin fields. In rocky settings it usually occurs in medium sized patches and does not occur evenly spread out throughout a site, probably due to lack of habitat.
Cracks in rocky outcrops and ledges in cool microsites and rocky alpine meadows. Mostly restricted to high elevation sites.

In New York this species is known mostly from tidal marshes along the Hudson River.  Most are freshwater although some are perhaps slightly brackish.  The plants also occur in adjacent swamps.  Also in acidic peat bogs and ponds (in one case planted and persisting in an acidic bog.)
Dry to mesic or occasionally wetter acidic northern forests often with Pinus strobus and thin soils.
Dry-mesic and stable high-terrace floodplain forests. A species of shaded habitats with well drained acidic to basic soils.
Rich mesic forests sometimes in thickets.  This species is more common that O. longistylis in New York and is not as much of a calciphile.
Rich forests, bottomlands, trail edges, and occasionally shaded not highly disturbed roadsides. .  This species often occurs in deep or calcareous soils but it can also be found in more acidic sites.

Swamps, wet and wet-mesic forests, edges of streams, and wet roadsides. Often in true wetlands but sometimes growing in more upland soils. It can be a little weedy. Sometimes with O. cinnamomea but also growing in drier and more disturbed habitats than the latter.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Osmunda regalis L. var. spectabilis (Willd.) A. Gray
Habitat: Swamps and stream edges it sometimes grows in inundated soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Osmundastrum cinnamomeum (L.) C. Presl var. cinnamomeum
Habitat: A variety of swamp types and wet woods. Mostly restricted to true swamps and sometimes forming very dense extensive patches.

An understory small tree it occurs in a variety of forested environments, woodlands, and rocky openings. It does best in thin forests and woodlands in rich dryish thin rocky soils and over calcareous bedrock. In these habitats it can become a dominant understory tree.
Cool northern forests and hummocks in swamps. It is a very common and often dominant herb in northern forests.
Cultivated ground, fields, pastures, disturbed soils in forests, stream banks, gravel and sand bars in streams, roadsides, and disturbed soils. A weedy species of disturbed soils in open habitats.
Dry to dry-mesic woodlands, rocky summits, and edges of forests. Local in distribution, populations are often isolated but sometimes consist of large patches.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Packera aurea (L.) Á. Löve & D. Löve
Habitat: Rich fens, swamps, seepages in forests and openings. Mostly a calciphile, Packera aurea does particularly well in mucky seepage areas.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Packera obovata (Muhl. ex Willd.) W.A. Weber & Á. Löve
Species_Author: (Muhl. ex Willd.) W.A. Weber & Á. Löve
Habitat: Dry-mesic to dry forests and woodlands; and road banks when the herbaceous vegetation is not too tall or thick. Prefers circumneutral to basic soils. Packera obovata forms small to medium sized clonal patches via stolons and rhizomes.
Rich mesic forests on or at base of slopes.  Populations often small although populations have apparently been depleted from widespread collecting at least formally.
Mesic forests and banks of small streams.  In rich to somewhat poorer soils.
Roadsides, disturbed soils, waste places, cultivated ground, and exposed gravel bars in streams.
Roadsides, disturbed soils, waste places, successional fields, cultivated ground, and exposed gravel bars in streams.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Panicum philadelphicum Bernh. ex Trin. ssp. gattingeri (Nash) Freckmann & Lelong
Panicum philadelphicum Bernh. ex Trin. ssp. philadelphicum

Habitat: Rich fens, calcareous rocky stream banks, and calcareous open to partly shaded seeps.

Shale and thin talus slopes, bluffs, thin deciduous forests, woodlands, trail edges, and banks of dirt roads. Mostly in disturbed or exposed thin dry to dry-mesic soils. It does not occur where there is much if any leaf litter.

Thin deciduous forests, woodlands, rocky summits, and roadsides. Mostly in disturbed thin dry soils. It occurs in similar habitats to P. canadensis but is much less common and perhaps tending to be in drier more open sites.
Mesic forests (particularly bottomland and young successional forests), forest edges, hedgerows, thickets, openings in forests, talus slopes, and rock outcrops.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Paspalum setaceum Michx. var. muhlenbergii (Nash) D.J. Banks
Habitat: Successional fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas in sandy soil.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Patis racemosa (Sm.) Romasch., P.M. Peterson & Soreng
Habitat: Dry-mesic to mesic often rocky forests. Sometimes but not restricted to areas with high pH soils. Appears to do best in forested areas with large boulders and rock outcrops.
Utility rights-of-way, dry to dry-mesic woodlands and thin canopied hardwood forests, forest openings, and bluffs.
Calcareous and marly fens, forested seeps; and swamps and margins of the Hudson River upslope from tidal influences.
Cliffs, ledges, talus slopes, and boulders in very thin dry soils over calcareous rock.
Bluffs, ledges, rock outcrops, non-shaded alvar habitats, thin soil over bedrock, and occasionally in disturbed sites. Perhaps most abundant over calcareous bedrock and soils.
Marshes, stream banks, swamps, and ditches.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Persicaria amphibia (L.) Delarbre ssp. laevimarginata (Hult.) Soják
Habitat: Rooted, floating leaved aquatic in ponds, lake edges, and marshes; it also occurs as an emergent in shallow water at edges of lakes, ponds, and slow moving streams; and grows as a terrestrial herb in saturated soils (at least seasonally) of pond and lake edges as well as marshes.
Swamps, marshes, and wet thickets.
Marshes and edges of ponds, lakes, and streams in saturated to inundated soils. Often in natural habitats and sometimes forming large dense patches.
Gravel and sand bars in streams, stream banks, floodplain thickets, disturbed sites, and waste places.
Gravel and sand bars of streams, floodplain thickets, ditches, and wet disturbed sites.
Brackish to fresh tidal and non-tidal marshes and swamps. Often in mucky saturated to slightly inundated soils.
Marshes, swamps, wet thickets, ditches, and wet disturbed sites.
Mesic forests and forest edges, floodplain forests and thickets, stream edges often but not restricted to rich deep wet-mesic to mesic soils.

Marshes, ditches, wet successional fields, wet hayfields, edges of ponds, stream banks, and openings in swamps. This species appears to do extremely well in areas with nutrient rich run off and often occurs in large dense populations.
Cool mesic hardwood, hemlock, and mixed coniferous-hardwoods forests.
Rich mesic to dry-mesic hardwood forests, edges of seeps, and edges of small streams. Generally but not restricted to mineral rich sites.
Mesic forests and forest edges in calcareous soils. Perhaps most common in floodplain forests.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Physalis longifolia Nutt. var. subglabrata (Mack. & Bush) Cronquist

Habitat: River banks, thickets in valley bottoms, and rock outcrops.
Cultivated and most wild populations probably represent introductions. Damp fields, ditches, and roadsides.
Tree fall gaps in forests, thickets, roadsides, and disturbed soils in native and non-native sites.
Bogs, swamps, edges of streams, wet depressions in cool northern forests, and high elevation forests. In the warmer parts of New York it is restricted to bogs and cool swamps.

A component of northern mixed coniferous-hardwood forests with Betula alleghaniensis, Fagus grandifolia, and Acer saccharum. In northern and cool areas it usually grows in thin mesic soils dropping out in the richer deeper soils where hardwoods dominant. Ascends to high elevation sites and also occurs occasionally near or in wetlands especially in the warmer and more southern parts of New York where it is a rare species.
Exposed gravel and sand bars in streams, low areas in swamps, floodplain forests, and disturbed soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Pilea pumila (L.) A. Gray var. pumila
Habitat: Exposed gravel and sand bars in streams, low areas in swamps, floodplain forests, disturbed soils, and cultivated ground.

Cultivated, planted in large plantations, and native. In central and western New York it occurs on steep south and west facing slopes and bluffs in dry rocky soils. In other parts of New York it occurs primarily on deep sandy soils or in pine barrens.
Common in pine barrens on deep sandy soils with a frequent fire regime. Also on dry rocky soils or thin soils over bedrock on hilltops, bluffs, crests, and steep south and west facing slopes.

Occurs in a wide variety of wet to dry habitats including mesic forests, dry rocky forests on slopes, successional fields and shrublands, lake edges, hummocks in swamps, rises in bogs, and elsewhere. Usually needing disturbances or openings to establish and therefore in many forests it is only a small component of the tree canopy. On lake edges and in areas regenerating from clearing or other disturbances it sometimes forms pure stands.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Piptatheropsis pungens (Torr. ex Spreng.) Romasch., P.M. Peterson & Soreng
Species_Author: (Torr. ex Spreng.) Romasch., P.M. Peterson & Soreng
Habitat: Dry to dry-mesic forests and forest openings.
Fresh tidal marshes and bays off of the Hudson River from just below to a little above high tide. Also along non tidal streams.
Fields, pastures, lawns, roadsides, and disturbed soils.
Fens, swamps, edges of streams, and wet ditches.
Bogs and peaty open wetlands in Sphagnum.
Bogs, open seepy habitats with thin soil, wet roadsides, and ditches. Sometimes quite common in previously disturbed wet open habitats.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Platanthera flava (L.) Lindl. var. herbiola (R. Br.) Luer

Habitat: Margins of streams, swamps, openings in swamps, marshes, and wet low forests.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Platanthera hookeri (Torr. ex A. Gray) Lindl.

Habitat: Wet fields and pastures and springy mucky herb dominated openings in swamps.
Mesic coniferous to hardwood forests often in thin acidic soils. Populations are often small and isolated.
Margins of streams, swamps, openings in swamps, marshes, and wet low forests.

Predominately a tree of riparian habitats including floodplain forests and thickets, edges of streams, and sand and gravel bars in streams. Occasionally isolated trees are found growing on lower to upper slopes away from streams.

Rich mesic forests and edges of paths and dirt roads through mesic forests. Appears to have an affinity for lightly disturbed soils in rich mesic forested sites and in such situations it can form large populations.
Swamps, marshes, ditches, wet disturbed areas, wet ledges, and fens.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Poa saltuensis Fernald & Wiegand ssp. languida (Hitchc.) A. Haines
Poa saltuensis Fernald & Wiegand ssp. saltuensis
Habitat: Mesic to dry-mesic forested sites dry banks of streams. Often but not restricted to high pH to circumneutral soils.
Rich mesic forests with high pH soils.
Mesic to dry-mesic deciduous forests, thin forests, thickets, and occasionally in fields, pastures, and relatively undisturbed road sides.

Peaty open wetlands including rich fens and acidic bogs. Perhaps more common in acidic bogs. It also grows adjacent to these habitats in disturbed upland soils including along abandoned railroad grades.

Gravel and sand bars of streams and disturbed areas. A very distinctive plant often occurring in open disturbed areas of streams that are seasonally flooded and the adjacent herbaceous vegetation is not thick.
Successional fields, forest edges and openings, thickets, and disturbed sites.
Roadsides, disturbed sites, forest openings, and successional fields with thin or dry soils and moderate to sparse herbaceous cover.
Acidic mesic hardwood and mixed coniferous-hardwood forests often with the adjacent herbaceous vegetation sparse. Often occurs with Gaultheria procumbens and the moss Leucobryum glaucum.

Mesic to dry hardwood forests, stream banks, alluvial thickets, woodlands, and edges of forests. Polygonatum biflorum sensu stricto usually occurs in drier, sandier or rockier habitats where P. pubescens does not occur.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Polygonatum biflorum (Walter) Elliott var. commutatum (Schult. f.) Morong

Habitat: Mesic rich to somewhat poorer hardwood forests and forested ledges.
Roadsides, pine barrens, dunes, and successional fields primarily in very sandy open sites.
Rocky summits and rock outcrops in forest openings, woodlands, and graminoid dominated native meadows. Often growing in cracks in non-shaded calcareous bedrock outcrops.
Rocky summits and rock outcrops in forest openings, woodlands, and graminoid dominated native meadows. Often occurring in cracks in non-shaded acidic bedrock outcrops.

Rims of cliffs, ledges, tops of boulders in forests, and talus slopes on thin mesic soil over rocks. Distinctions in habitat preferences between this and the very closely related P. virginianum as well as the hybrid between the two (P. x incognitum) have not been detected.

Rims of cliffs, ledges, tops of boulders in forests, and talus slopes on thin mesic soil over rocks. Distinctions in habitat preferences between this and the very closely related P. appalachianum as well as the hybrid between the two (P. x incognitum) have not been detected.

A common mesic hardwood forest understory species in the parts of New York that have richer soils. In the more acidic as well as the more northern parts of New York, it becomes less common and more restricted to rich and rocky soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Polystichum acrostichoides × P. braunii = P. ×potteri Barrington
Habitat: Cool rich woods.
Cool rich mesic to wet-mesic hardwood or coniferous-hardwood forests. Grows predominately in calcareous sites or low on slopes in deep soils.
In standing water at edges of ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Populus balsamifera × P. deltoides = P. ×jackii Sarg.
Populus deltoides W. Bartram ex Marshall ssp. deltoides
Habitat: Floodplain and low forests, streamsides, gravel and sand bars in streams, ditches, swamps, and occasionally on upper and middle slopes of hardwood mesic forests.
Successional forests, logged forests, burned forests, forest edges, openings in forests, successional fields, and roadsides.
Successional forests, logged forests, burned forests, forest edges, openings in forests, successional fields, and roadsides.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of lakes and streams.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of lakes and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of lakes and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of lakes and slow moving streams.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes, and slow moving streams sometimes becoming stranded when water levels drop.
Shallow circumneutral to alkaline water of lakes and slow moving streams.
Shores of ponds, lakes, and streams, thickets, and disturbed sites often in sandy wet to wet-mesic soils.
Successional fields, forests, utility rights-of-way, disturbed soils, and roadsides in thin or sandy dry to dry-mesic soils.
Roadsides, disturbed sites, successional fields, forest edges, open rock outcrops, and openings in forests.
Successional fields, pastures, hayfields, roadsides, forests (primarily young successional), forests openings, edges of paths through forests, rocky summits, and rock outcrops.
Hedgerows, thickets, forest edges, young successional forests, and disturbed soils often in valley bottoms and floodplains.
Edges of forests, successional forests, logged areas, burned areas, forest openings, rocky summits, rock outcrops, cliffs, ledges, and bluffs.
Hardwood forests, forest edges, and hedge rows. A major forest tree in hardwood forests preferring rich mesic soils.
Rocky summits, exposed rocky ridges, rock outcrops, bluffs, and ledges. Also rarely occurs in open fields with thin seasonally saturated and seasonally dry soils.
Thickets, hardwood forests, forest edges, hedgerows, and roadsides.
Disturbed soils, cut forests, and edges of fields. Perhaps becoming less common as the forests are returning to post agricultural lands.

Successional fields, roadsides, edges of forests and woodlands, and disturbed ground. This species does well in thin soils. It appears to have decreased in abundance in parts of the state during the 1900's perhaps due to agricultural fields growing back to forests.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Pteridium aquilinum (L.) Kuhn ssp. latiusculum (Desv.) Hultén
Habitat: Hardwood or pine forests, utility rights-of-way, fields, and thickets. Mostly in thin acidic soils and often associated with Vaccinium and Gaylussacia species.
Dry-mesic hardwood forests, woodlands, rocky summits, and edges of fields. Mostly a plant of dry partly shaded habitats. It is much more abundant in warmer and more southern parts of New York.
Rocky summits, thickets, fields, roadsides, and railroad edges in dry to seasonally wet soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Pycnanthemum virginianum (L.) Durieu & Jacks. ex Fernald & B. Robinson
Species_Author: (L.) Durieu & Jacks. ex Fernald & B. Robinson
Habitat: Edges of marshes, fields, thickets, and railroad edges in wet to dry soils.
Hardwood or pine-hardwood forests with dry to mesic acidic sandy or coarse soils and sandy roadsides. Fairly common in sandy forests on Long Island.

Rich calcareous swamps and fens, cool wet-mesic to mesic hardwood and hardwood-coniferous forests, forest edges, and edges of streams in forests. Probably not as rare as previously believed this species is perhaps overlooked when growing in cool northern mesic forests.
Cool northern mesic forests and edges of swamps.
Mesic forests. The most common Pyrola in non-sandy mesic forests.

Dry to mesic forests. Tolerant of a wide variety of soil types it is lacking in the most xeric woodlands, in cool habitats, and in the richest deepest soils. Some forests were previously selectively logged for this species and perhaps as a result white oak is less frequent than it was formerly.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Quercus alba × Q. montana = Q. ×saulii C.K. Schneid.

Habitat: Swamps, wet depressions, and thickets. Often in swamps on ridges and hill tops. Always in at least seasonally wet soils this species is often absent from deep alluvial soils where Quercus macrocarpa occurs.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Quercus bicolor × Q. macrocarpa = Q. ×schuettei Trel.

Habitat: Dry to dry-mesic forests and woodlands. Predominately on very dry ridges, hilltops, crests, and upper slopes. Perhaps a fire dependent species it can often form dense monospecific stands, and sometimes in the driest situations, the trees appear dwarfed.
Pine and other barrens, rocky summits, openings in woodlands, and utility rights-of way. Often on upper slopes, crests, and hilltops in dry acidic thin, sandy, or rocky soils.

Dry to dry-mesic acidic forests and woodlands. A good indicator of thin dry acidic soils it usually occurs on upper slopes, crests, ridges, and hill tops often with an understory of ericaceous shrubs including Kalmia latifolia, Vaccinium spp, and Gaylussacia baccata.
Cultivated as well as native. It occurs primarily in small acidic swamps and forested depressions.

Pine and other barrens, rocky summits, opening in woodlands, and utility rights-of way. Often on upper slopes, crests, and hilltops in dry acidic thin, sandy, or rocky soils. Occurs in very similar habitat to Q. ilicifolia but is less common and populations are often not very abundant.

The most widespread oak species in New York. Dry to mesic forests in a variety of soil types. It occurs in the coolest climates of any species of oak in New York as well as in warmer more southern forest types.
Dry to mesic forests. Prefers two main habitats: dry ridges and upper slopes sometimes with Q. coccinea; and deep slightly acidic often sandy mesic soils on mid to lower slopes.
Rich mesic to dry-mesic forests, thickets, forested rock outcrops, cliffs, talus slopes, and edges of dirt roads and paths through forests.

Common_Name: northern swamp buttercup, northern swamp crowfoot
Habitat: Swamps, rich fens, marshes, wet thickets, and edges of lakes in inundated to saturated mucky soils.
Dry-mesic forests and forest edges, alvar habitats, and summits of cliffs and rock outcrops. Primarily in open to partly shaded dry to dry-mesic calcareous habitats.

Common_Name: yellow water buttercup, yellow water crowfoot

Habitat: Dry-mesic to mesic forested slopes and summits, and thickets in thin rocky calcareous to circumneutral soils.
Wet to wet-mesic seepy forested rock outcrops, ledges, and adjacent soils.
Mesic to wet-mesic hardwood forests and less frequently hummocks in swamps.
Ditches, wet waste places, disturbed sites, edges of streams and lakes, and wet forests.

Common_Name: southern swamp buttercup, southern swamp crowfoot

Habitat: Rich fens, swamps, and occasionally on dry calcareous rock outcrops. Primarily a wetland species but at times growing in xeric soils. At least in the southern and warmer parts of New York, this species is a strong calciphile.
Pond and lake shores, edges of streams, and thickets in wet peaty or sandy soils. Primarily in full sun.
In cracks in rock ledges and cliffs.
Bogs, edges of bogs, and wet thickets.
Swamps, edges of ponds, and occasionally in wet forests. In central and western New York it is restricted to small disjunct patches in cool swamps. In southeastern New York it becomes more common.

Dry to dry-mesic forests, forest edges, bluffs, hummocks and edges of swamps, and utility rights-of-way. Primarily a species of slightly open dry acidic oak dominated forests but also somewhat frequent on hummocks in swamps.

Acidic swamps, swamp edges, and edges of ponds. Usually bordering small acidic ponds with various other tall shrubs including Clethra alnifolia, Vaccinium corymbosum, and Nemopanthus mucronatus. Most common in the more southern parts of New York and restricted or absent from the rest of the state.
Thin forests, edges of forests, openings, rocky openings, and thickets.  Often in sandy or calcareous soils.
Exposed rocky ridges, burned over areas, thickets, and fields.  Soils often dry and sandy.
A pioneer species.  Similar habitat to R. typhina but perhaps a little less common.  Old fields, edges of fields, roadsides, shrubby thickets, stream banks, and edges of forests.
A pioneer species.  Old  fields, edges of fields, roadsides, shrubby thickets, open stream banks, and edges of forests.

Peatlands both basic and acidic including rich fens, poor fens, and acidic bogs. In these habitats it grows in heavily saturated and inundated soils often where the mat is not as well formed advising the botanist not to step in these areas.
Sandy open habitats.
Edge of acid lakes.
Floodplain forests, thickets, and stream edges. Often in deep well drained alluvium.
Mesic hardwood forests, successional forests, forest edges, and thickets. Mostly in somewhat to very calcareous soils.
Swamps, shrub swamps, seepage areas, and marshes. Mostly at least in part shade. More common in the northern and cooler parts of New York.
Open and shrubby rich fens and rich swamps.
Cool swamps, wet thickets, and wet cool hardwood-coniferous and coniferous forests. Most abundant and common in the cooler and more northern parts of New York.
Rocky dry-mesic forests, sometimes associated with talus slopes or bases of cliffs and ledges. Predominately in acidic soils in southeastern New York.
Cool swamps, edges of streams, wet thickets, and wet cool hardwood-coniferous and coniferous forests. Most abundant and common in the cooler and more northern parts of New York.
Edges of forests, thin canopied forests, woodlands, edges of paths and dirt roads through forests, successional fields, and forests openings. Generally in dry to dry-mesic soils.
Swamps, edges of streams and lakes, marshes, and rich shrubby fens.
Forest edges, logged forests, thickets, dirt road sides, and disturbed soils in forests.
Cool northern forests and ledges and rock outcrops in forests in mesic to wet-mesic soils.
Roadsides, edges of railroads, talus slopes, forest openings, open rocky summits, and bluffs.
Cool swamps and swamp edges, peatlands, wet-mesic to cool mesic forests, and roadsides often in mosses.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Rubus idaeus L. ssp. strigosus (Michx.) Focke
Habitat: Logged forests, forest openings, tip-up mounds at bases of fallen trees, roadsides, disturbed sites, talus slopes, and rocky openings. Very common and widespread in the cooler parts of New York and less widespread and more of a habitat specialist in the warmer parts of the state.
Successional and disturbed forests, floodplain forests, forest edges, openings in forests, thickets, stream banks, and roadsides.
Forest edges, talus slopes, mesic rocky outcrops, disturbed soils in forests, and thickets. Generally in wet-mesic or sometimes mesic soils and often in at least partly shaded habitats.
Roadsides, forest edges, successional fields, and pastures.
Swamps, wet thickets, peatlands, and cool mesic to wet-mesic forests often in mosses.
Cool hardwood and coniferous forests as well as hummocks in forested swamps. Predominately in shaded habitats with wet-mesic soils.
Alluvial forests and thickets, wet talus slopes, edges of streams, and wet thickets.
Marshes, swamps, and wet thickets. Often in unshaded to partly shaded habitats. Sometimes forming large populations.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Sabulina michauxii (Fenzl) Dillenb. & Kadereit var. michauxii
Habitat: Rocky summits, woodlands, open forests, ledges, and alvar often in dry thin soils. Rocks and soils are often calcareous.

Perhaps our most common Sagittaria this species occurs in a wide variety of wetlands.  It often occurs in standing water and occasionally on seasonally exposed soils.  Margins of ponds and streams, marshes, ditches and channels.
Edges of ponds.
Occurs in tidal mud flats which can be brackish or fresh.  This species can occur in large stands and is often fully submerged during high tide.
Occurs in tidal mud flats both brackish and fresh.  Like S. montevidensis ssp. spongiosa which this species occurs with it can form large stands and is fully submerged during high tide.
Edges of lakes, floodplain forests, and streamsides.
Swamps, rich fens, wet thickets, wet successional fields, roadsides, ditches, marshes, vernal pools, and edges of lakes and streams.
Shrubby or herb dominated rich fens and sometimes in calcareous swamps and swamp openings.
Swamps, rich fens, wet thickets, wet successional fields, roadsides, ditches, marshes, vernal pools, and edges of lakes and streams.
Swamps, wet thickets, wet successional fields, roadsides, ditches, marshes, and edges of lakes and streams.
Forest edges, forest openings, occasionally in thin forests, successional fields, utility rights-of-way, ditches, and perhaps sparsely in wetlands.
Shrub swamps, stream and lake edges, rich fens, ditches, and wet thickets. Populations are often isolated and small.
Edges of rivers and streams, wet thickets, marshes, low and floodplain forests, and edges of lakes.
Shrub swamps including rich shrubby fens, wet thickets, and edges of streams and lakes.
Swamps, rich fens, wet thickets, wet successional fields, roadsides, ditches, marshes, and edges of lakes and streams.
Rich herb or shrub dominated fens and calcareous swamps.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Sambucus nigra L. ssp. canadensis (L.) Bolli
Habitat: Marshes, thickets, and stream banks. Mostly in non or only slightly shaded habitats and usually wet or seasonally flooded (sometimes mesic) soils.
Cool mesic forests, rocky forested slopes, roadsides in cooler parts of the state, and thickets. Mostly in shaded habitats.
Brackish marshes (including tidal ones) and pond and wetland edges.
Rich mesic to dry-mesic hardwood forests. In more acidic regions it often occurs in rocky sites.
Rich fens, river and ice scour meadows along rivers, and stream banks.

Common_Name: common Canada sanicle, common Canada snakeroot
Habitat: Mesic forests and thickets at least sometimes in rich sites.
Rich mesic forests, alluvial forests, and occasionally hummocks in rich swamps.  This is perhaps our most common Sanicula and occurs in the widest array of habitats.
Rich deciduous and floodplain forests.
Acidic to alkaline peatlands.
Mesic to dry forests, edges of forests, woodlands, talus slopes, bluffs, sand dunes, dry stream banks, pastures, hedge rows, successional fields, and road banks. Often in sandy or gravely soils.
Shallow water at edges of slow moving streams, edges of lakes, wet areas in bottomland and riparian forests, swamps, and swamp openings. Sometimes forming large dense populations.
Mesic to dry-mesic forested sites often in rocky, high pH well-drained soils.
Rocky summits, openings in woodlands and thin canopied forests, successional fields, roadsides, stream banks, and pine barrens. Generally in open dry sites.

Edges of pond, lakes, and large to medium sized rivers. Also known from fresh intertidal shores of the Hudson River. Smith (2002) states that this taxon grows in areas with relatively little water-level fluctuations but at least in NY it sometimes occurs in areas with large water fluctuations like along the tidal Hudson River.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Schoenoplectiella smithii (A. Gray) Hayas. var. smithii
Habitat: Freshwater tidal habitats or areas with significant water fluctuation including edges of large lakes and rivers.
Edge of lakes, streams, rivers, and ponds; and marshes. In fresh to brackish water including inland salt marshes. Often in gravel, sand, or coarse soils.

Emergent in marshes; edges of lakes, ponds, and slow-moving streams; fens; roadside ditches; and disturbed inundated soils. One of the most common Schoenoplectus in at least parts of New York, it grows in pristine rare habitats like rich fens as well as in disturbed areas. It usually is emergent from perennially inundated soils to sometimes only seasonally inundated soils.
Marshes, edges of streams and ponds, wet ditches, and wet logging roads. Soils are mostly at least perennially saturated but plants can sometimes be found in slightly drier situations.
Marshes, openings in swamps, roadside ditches, and less frequently wet fields. Often but not always in somewhat wetter more native and less disturbed habitats than S. hattorianus.

Marshes, edges of ponds, openings in swamps, wet fields, and wet ditches. Except perhaps in the northern parts of New York the most common of the wool grasses (S. atrocinctus, S. cyperinus, and S. pedicellatus).
Marshes and seepage areas.
Marshes, wet fields, and wet roadsides. Often grows in the drier parts of marshes and in slightly saturated or simply wet-mesic soils.

Marshes, fields, thickets, and roadside ditches. Most common in fields and disturbed sites. Does best in heavy or poorly drained soils that become seasonally saturated or slightly inundated including compacted soils of paths and dirt roads. More common in drier and more disturbed habitats than S. atrovirens.
Marshes, sedge meadows, edges of streams, and wet logging roads.
Wet fields, roadsides ditches, and disturbed wet-mesic soils. Mostly in association with calcareous soils. Usually in only seasonally saturated or inundated soils.
Marshes and openings in swamps.
Dry-mesic to mesic thin canopied forests, woodlands, and forest edges. Predominately in thin or well drained rocky soils.
Floodplain forests and thickets, banks of streams, gravel bars in streams, edges of dirt roads, and occasionally in mesic hardwood forests.
Openings in swamps, marshes, and edges of ponds and streams.
Seeps in forests, swamps, marshes, and edges of streams. Occurs in both shaded and unshaded wet habitats.
Rich fens, seepages, wet utility rights-of-way, wet non-shaded thickets, and stream banks. Often where the adjacent herbaceous vegetation is thin.
Dry rock outcrops, ledges, and thin soil over bedrock.
Edge of forests, thickets, roadsides, and disturbed soils.
Open bluffs, thin forests, utility rights-of- way, and non-forested habitat in dry to dry-mesic thin soils.

Alpine meadows, open rocky summits, rocky ridges, heath meadows, and forest openings. Prefers full sun and thin soils in rock outcrops. Fairly local in southern New York outside of the Catskill Mountains.
Bottomland forests and thickets, and pond margins. Occurs in deep rich mesic to wet-mesic forests. Similar habitat affinities to Echinocystis lobata.

Rocky summits, outcrops, and slopes; thin talus slopes, woodlands, roadsides, railroad edges, and disturbed soils. Mostly a plant of native dry rocky open habitats although also found in more disturbed non-native habitats. In dry years plants senesce early.

Thin deciduous forests and woodlands often on rocky slopes with dry to dry-mesic calcareous or mineral rich soils. A thin delicate herb mostly occurring in small populations in understories of thin forests. The adjacent herbaceous layer is usually not tall or dense but quite diverse.
Fields, pastures, thickets, successional shrub lands, and occasionally gaps and openings in forests. Mostly in fields in unshaded habitats.
Fields and pastures.
Standing water in swamps, edges and backwaters of streams, and channels through marshes.  This species can grow in deep water.  Leaves in deep water are finely dissected.
Mesic forests, forest edges, and thickets. Plants in dense shade often are small and remain vegetative. Populations generally consist of only a few individuals or small patches.
Wet thickets, marshes, swamps, and mesic to wet forested sites. Populations are often relatively small in number.

In dry to wet forests and forest edges of a south affinity; dry thickets and roadsides. It does particularly well in warm successional forests where it can dominate the understory and climb into the canopy. This species often forms large impenetrable thickets.
Roadsides, disturbed sites, pastures, successional fields, cultivated ground, floodplain forests, and thickets.
Waste places, disturbed soils, roadsides, cultivated ground, pastures, successional fields, thickets, thin soils on bedrock, and ledges.

Successional fields, pastures, road banks, and disturbed soil. Sometimes occurring in disturbed soil in forested situations but clearly doing best in open areas. Forms dense patches in successional fields and is one of our most common goldenrods except in the northern part of the state.
Dry-mesic to mesic deciduous forests often along the edge of trails, forest edges, and occasionally roadsides. Mainly in shaded dryish situations.

Thin forests, woodlands and opening, edges of forests, roadside banks where the herbaceous vegetation is not tall or dense, and successional fields in dry to mesic often thin soils.  Does best without intense herbaceous competition.

Forested slopes, forest edges, forested road banks, and shale talus in mesic to a little drier soils. Occurring almost entirely in shaded situations Solidago caesia can be quite abundant at a site although it usually does not occur in dense stands.

Wet-mesic to dry-mesic successional fields, pastures, road banks, disturbed soil, clearings or openings in forests, and forests. In forested environments this species occurs in small numbers often in disturbed soils. It is a small somewhat less aggressive plant than S. altissima and prefers slightly wetter soils.

Rich mesic forests, forested road banks, edges of forests, and thickets. Prefers deep calcareous soils. Solidago flexicaulis is an understory herb of mesic forested environments. In the northern parts of NY it is more restricted to rich forests while in the southern parts of NY it grows in a wider variety of soils although still prefers the richer sites.

Swamps, wet forests, wet fields, and thickets. Solidago gigantea does best in saturated soils although it tolerates soils that are simply mesic, at least seasonally. It usually does not occur in dense stands.
Dry to dry-mesic rocky forested slopes and woodlands, edges of forests, and bluffs. Grows where the herbaceous vegetation is not dense or tall.
Successional fields, edges of forests, woodlands, and road banks. Grows where the soils are thin. It does best in full light where the adjacent herbaceous vegetation is low in stature.

Clearings and openings in forests of a northern affinity, forests and forest edges, and ledges.  This is a northern plant occurring in our cooler and more northern areas it ascends to sub-alpine forests. It does particularly well in openings in forests but also grows well in undisturbed cool forested sites.

Woodlands, edges of forests, successional fields, bluffs, and road banks. Grows in dry to mesic thin poor soils but tends to do best in the drier sites. The adjacent herbaceous vegetation is thin and not tall.
Roadsides, woodlands, and rocky openings. A more southern species occurring with us in only the more southern parts of NY.

Rich swamps, fens, seepage areas in forests, and marshes. Restricted to saturated or seasonally inundated soils. It does best in rich more open environments but also occurs in fairly well shaded swamps.
Acidic dry rocky ledges and outcrops, cracks and fissures in rocks, thin rocky slopes of forests, and roadsides.

Successional fields, pastures, wet to mesic forests, swamps, and roadsides. A common widespread species it can form dense large patches in fields. It prefers at least slightly wetter than mesic soils although it grows in mesic conditions as well.
Successional fields and edges of forests in sandy soil.
Thin dry forests and woodlands (including alvar and limestone types), shale and fine talus slopes, and roadsides.
Open to partially forested wet peatlands from rich fens and swamps to more acidic "bogs". Usually not in mineral soil swamps or marshes but restricted to the more unique peatland environments.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Solidago ulmifolia Muhl. ex Willd. var. ulmifolia
Habitat: Usually dry to occasionally more mesic rocky deciduous forests, woodlands, forest edges, and bluffs. Mostly a forest or woodland species. Perhaps preferring calcareous soils.

Cool northern coniferous to hardwood forests, sub-alpine forests, forest edges and openings, open rocky ridges and summits, and talus slopes. Fairy common and widespread in the cooler and northern parts of New York. Less common and more of a habitat specialist in the southern and warmer parts of the state. Seedlings and perhaps very young saplings can be quite common in a variety of forested habitats in some parts of southern New York but mostly do not appear to survive for more than a few year.

Cool northern coniferous to hardwood forests, sub-alpine forests, forest edges and openings, open rocky ridges and summits, and talus slopes. Often in cooler and higher elevation sites than Sorbus americana. Sometimes cultivated and perhaps also naturalizing from these plantings.
Ice and river scour shores of large rivers, roadsides, occasionally in fens, and open thickets.
Edges of lakes, ponds, and slow moving streams; channels in swamps, marshes, and rich fens; and marshes. This species generally occurs in shallow water on mucky soils.
Edges of lakes, ponds, and slow moving streams; channels in swamps, marshes, and rich fens; and marshes. This species generally occurs in shallow water on mucky soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Sparganium eurycarpum Engelm. ex A. Gray
Habitat: Edges of lakes, ponds, and slow moving streams; channels in swamps, marshes, and peatlands; and marshes. This species grows in shallow water and is often associated with large extensive marshes.
Rich mesic to dry-mesic forests, fens and marshes. Perhaps more common in high pH sites. Populations are often small with plants widely scattered.

Dry to mesic forests and forest edges. It does well in successional forests. It often grows in cool shaded sites but is not restricted to such habitats and ascends into the sub-alpine and alpine zones.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Spiraea alba Du Roi var. latifolia (Aiton) Dippel
Habitat: Streamside meadows, swamps, wet forests, marshes, peatlands, wet thickets, forest openings, ditches, and thin soil over bedrock on exposed open rocky summits.
Streamside meadows, wet thickets, ditches, peatlands, swamps, and marshes.
Rich fens and calcareous seepy habitats with thin soils. Does well in or on the edges of rivulets through fens which have marly rocky soils.
Dry to dry-mesic oak dominated forests and woodlands.
Quiet waters of ponds, lakes, marshes, and streams.
Upper edges of salt marshes, ice and river scour shores, exposed gravel bars in rivers, fresh water marshes, and lake shores.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Sporobolus vaginiflorus (Torr. ex A. Gray) Alph. Wood var. vaginiflorus
Habitat: Roadsides, disturbed sites, and waste places. Common on road edges adjacent to traffic.

Rocky forests, rock outcrops, thin soils on exposed calcareous bedrock, banks of forested streams, and mesic forests (particularly floodplain forests) and thickets. Prefers dry to mesic highly calcareous sites but when in rocky forested sites it may not be as strong of a calciphile.
Springs, mucky seepage areas, small stream edges, and wet low forests. Sometimes appearing as a native in native habitats, often in cool wet sites, and usually with some tree canopy cover.

Springs and spring runs, openings in swamps, seeps, and springy edges of small rivulets and streams. Often in areas which are perennially wet, cool, without a dense canopy cover, and without dense tall herbaceous vegetation. Sometimes growing in mosses.

Banks of small streams in cool hardwood-coniferous or coniferous forests. Also in seepage areas, hummocks in swamps, and wet cool forests. Most common in the coolest parts of New York. Populations are often small and individual plants are often widely scattered throughout the appropriate habitat.
Cool mesic hardwood and hardwood-coniferous forests. Most common in the coolest and more northern parts of New York.
Shallow water of ponds, lakes and slow moving streams.

Thin forests, woodlands, edges of forests, trails and paths in forests, rocky slopes, and disturbed soils. Perhaps its preferred habitat is along edges of forests where it gets a lot of light but herbaceous competition is minimal.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum ericoides (L.) G.L. Nesom var. ericoides
Symphyotrichum laeve (L.) Á. Löve & D. Löve var. laeve
Habitat: Dry rocky forested slopes, woodlands, edges of forests, roadsides, occasionally fields, and thickets. Does particularly well in calcareous soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum lanceolatum (Willd.) G.L. Nesom var. lanceolatum
Habitat: Floodplain forests and thickets, successional fields, wet forests, swamps, stream banks, roadsides, and ditches. A vigorous spreader this species is quite weedy and has long rhizomes that can form large clonal patches. It grows in a variety of habitats from dry to wet and from open to shaded.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum lateriflorum (L.) Á. Löve & D. Löve
Habitat: Successional fields, roadsides, woodlands, openings in forests, disturbed areas, and less frequently on stream banks and in swamps.

Dry rocky forested slopes, edges of forests, and occasionally fields. This species resembles S. cordifolium although it is distinct and is much less frequent than S. cordifolium. Symphyotrichum lowrieanum perhaps prefers more calcareous, drier, and more open habitats than S. cordifolium.
Successional fields, roadsides, and waste places. Frequently in dry to mesic sites and less frequently in wetter soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum patens (Aiton) G.L. Nesom var. patens
Habitat: Rocky summits, woodlands, and dry rocky forested slopes. A southern species with us mostly in warmer and southern parts of NY.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum pilosum (Willd.) G.L. Nesom var. pilosum
Habitat: Roadsides, successional fields, pastures, waste places, and disturbed areas. A weedy species very commonly along roads and in disturbed soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum pilosum (Willd.) G.L. Nesom var. pringlei (A. Gray) G.L. Nesom
Habitat: Dry successional fields, utility line cuts, edges of forested areas, and roadsides. Compared to the typical variety, var. pringlei grows in drier sites with less herbaceous competition, and more often is in more native type habitats.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum prenanthoides (Muhl. ex Willd.) G.L. Nesom
Habitat: Swamps, wet ditches, thickets, stream banks and gravel bars, and seepage areas. Usually in wet to wet-mesic soil or soils that are seasonally wet. Often with some amount of canopy cover although most robust in open sites.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symphyotrichum puniceum (L.) Á. Löve & D. Löve var. puniceum
Habitat: Swamps, marshes, fens, wet thickets, stream banks, and ditches. A common aster of various wetland types and usually not too weedy.
Successional fields, roadsides, shores of lakes, and disturbed soils. With us mostly in dry to mesic soils in southeastern NY.
Forest edges, woodlands, rocky open forests, edges of forests, bluffs, and occasionally roadsides. Grows in dry to mesic soils but more often in drier soils.
Successional fields, openings in forests, and roadsides. Almost entirely a field species/ Late in the season its white panicles can easily be spotted poking above the other herbaceous vegetation.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Symplocarpus foetidus (L.) Salisb. ex W.P.C. Barton
Habitat: Seepage springs and slopes, swamps, and wet floodplain forests.  Symplocarpus foetidus is common in a variety of shaded wetlands although it does have a preference for cold seepage areas and mucky soils.

Thin forests, non weedy clearings and forest openings, rims of ravines, and shale talus slopes. The soils are often dry, rocky, and calcareous.  This species appears to need a lot of light to flower and become vigorous although it does not do well with herbaceous competition.  It also is much more abundant in calcareous regions.  Its habitat preferences are similar to Zizia aptera except perhaps for the preferences for calcareous sites.

Cool mesic to wet-mesic hardwood to mixed coniferous-hardwood forests, shaded talus slopes, and hummocks in swamps. Highly prized by deer and in areas with an overpopulation of deer becoming restricted to steep slopes and tops of boulders that are inaccessible to deer browse.
Rocky summits, talus slopes, woodlands, and bluffs. Primarily a species of dry rocky soils in unshaded habitats. Occurs in the more southern and warmer parts of New York.
Floodplain forests, alluvial thickets, edges of streams, and sand and gravel bars in streams. Sometimes somewhat weedy.
Mesic hardwood forests and forest edges in thin to deep often calcareous or circumneutral soils.
Rich fens, stream banks, swamps, marshes, and wet thickets.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Thalictrum thalictroides (L.) A.J. Eames & B. Boivin
Habitat: Hardwood forests, forest edges, openings in forests, edges of forested dirt roads on mid to upper slopes and usually in thin dry-mesic coarse grained or rocky circumneutral to calcareous soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Thelypteris palustris Schott var. pubescens (G. Lawson) Fernald
Habitat: Marshes, rich fens, and swamps; edges of ponds, lakes, and streams; and ditches and open wet thickets.

Calcareous cliffs and ledges, rocky summits, alvars, fens, and rich swamps. Grows in both xeric and wet, often cool sites. Mostly confined to calcareous soils and bedrock. In northern and cooler parts of New York it become less of a calciphile. In swamps it can from dense impenetrable stands.
