Mesic hardwood forests, edges of forested seeps, and hummocks in swamps. Generally found in valley bottoms or on lower slopes.

Rich mesic forests, talus slopes, bases of rock outcrops, bluffs, and thin soil over calcareous bedrock. Although occurring throughout New York's mesic hardwood forests excepting the cooler parts of the state this species is most abundant in deep rich mesic soils of valley bottoms and lower slopes as well as on talus slopes and in association with rocky outcrops.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Torreyochloa pallida (Torr.) G.L. Church var. fernaldii (Hitchc.) Dore
Habitat: Edges of ponds and lakes, stream margins, and marshes. Often in slightly inundated to saturated mucky soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Torreyochloa pallida (Torr.) G.L. Church var. pallida

Habitat: Talus slopes, bases of cliffs, rich mesic forests, wet forests, swamps, and disturbed ground.  It occurs in a variety of habitats but does particularly well in calcareous and rich sites.
Swamps, calcareous marshes, and rich fens.  Although it does occur in swamps it does best in opening in swamps or where the canopy is not too dense.  It is mostly restricted to calcareous wet sites.

Dry to mesic hardwood forests of a southern affinity, woodlands, and bluffs. Often in forests with oaks and hickories dominant. Usually in forests that are not very weedy and the adjacent herbaceous layer is not very dense.
Rocky summits, rock outcrops, railroad edges, and thickets in dry thin gravelly or sandy soils.
Roadsides, sandy successional fields, gravel pits, and openings in forests in dry to dry-mesic sandy or gravely soils.
Mesic hardwood and hardwood-coniferous forests. Occurs in a wide variety of forested habitats although it is absent from the warmer drier more open sites.
Rich mesic hardwood forests growing from the base of valleys to middle slopes. Sometimes forming dense large patches.

Cool coniferous, northern hardwood, and hardwood-coniferous forests. Sometimes on hummock in swamps. In more southern parts of New York often under Tsuga canadensis. Most common in the northern and cooler parts of New York.

Burned over forests, woodlands, thin forests, rocky outcrops and summits, trail and dirt road edges, railroad edges, and disturbed areas. A species of disturbed or thin mostly dry to a little moister soils.

Rich forests, edges of forests, stream sides, and thickets often in deep and/or calcareous soils. The soils vary from mesic to dry. Plants are usually not present throughout a site but are more restricted to a few dense patches.
Cool mesic to wet-mesic forests sometimes associated with Tsuga canadensis.
Rich fens and northern white cedar swamps.

A component of mesic cool northern forests throughout New York. In these sites it more often occurs with hardwoods and Pinus strobus than with other conifers. Also commonly on hummocks in swamps where it can sometimes form dense pure stands; often in pure stands, in ravines and on north and east facing lower slopes; and on rocky outcrops and bluffs.
Successional fields, roadsides, and disturbed places often in thin dry soils. A native species almost always found in non-native habitats.

Brackish and fresh tidal and non-tidal marshes, ditches, pond and lake edges, openings in swamps, and wet thickets. Although the prominent cattail of saline areas it is also widespread in non-saline habitats.
Fresh tidal and non-tidal marshes, ditches, pond and lake edges, stream sides, swamps, wet thickets, and rich fens.

Wet thickets, stream edges, swamps, roadsides, mesic to wet forests, and forest edges. In wet to mesic often nutrient rich soils. Still a rather common tree even after the introduction of Dutch Elm Disease although perhaps not as significant of a component of bottom land and wet-mesic forests and not growing as large as in the past.
Dry to mesic forests, forest edges, openings in forests, rock outcrops, and stream sides generally in calcareous sites.
High and low forested floodplain terraces, floodplain thickets, and gravel and sand bars in streams.
Rooted on peaty shores of ponds and in bogs.
Quiet water of ponds and edges of lakes.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Utricularia vulgaris L. ssp. macrorhiza (LeConte) R.T. Clausen
Habitat: Floating in quiet water of lakes, ponds, and streams.
Forests, woodlands, and bluffs in dry to dry-mesic often rocky soils with oaks dominant
Mesic to dry-mesic northern hardwood forests in thin acidic soils. Very common in the northern and cooler parts of New York.
Dry to dry-mesic acidic forests, rocky summits, woodlands, barrens, rocky alpine areas, and fields with thin soils. Mostly in thin dry acidic rocky soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Vaccinium angustifolium × V. corymbosum = V. ×atlanticum E.P. Bicknell

Habitat: In a wide variety of wetlands and also in dry thin soils on crests and upper slopes. Rich fens, acidic bogs, swamps, shrub swamps, wet thickets, edges of marshes, and mesic forests.
Wet Sphagnum peatlands in acidic to more minerotrophic sites including rich fens and acidic bogs.
Hummocks in swamps, edges of swamps, cool northern forests, edges of forests, forest openings, barrens, and bluffs. More common in the northern and cooler parts of New York.
Acidic bogs and wet seepy disturbed soils.
Dry to dry-mesic hardwood forests, edges of forests, woodlands, rocky summits, barrens, and old fields. Often associated with other Vaccinium spp. and ericaceous shrubs.
Dry to dry-mesic hardwood forests, edges of forests, and bluffs. Often on ridges, hill tops, or upper slopes in thin dry rocky acidic soils.
Lakes, streams, rivers, and tidal bays.
Edges of forested streams, seepages, swamps in mucky soils, and low wet forests. Sometimes forms dense patches.
Marshes, gravel bars in streams, ditches and wet successional fields.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Verbena hastata × V. urticifolia = V. ×engelmannii Moldenke

Habitat: Disturbed soils, roadsides, successional fields, thickets, forested openings, and edges of forests in wet to mesic soils.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Vernonia gigantea (Walter) Trel. ex Branner & Coville
Habitat: Seasonally wet fields.
Wet successional fields, stream banks, and wet forests. Fairly limited in distribution in NY and with us, usually not forming large stands.
Ditches, stream edges, wet thickets, swamps, and gravel and sand bars in streams.
Marshes, low areas in swamps in mucky saturated to slightly inundated soils, ditches, and stream edges.
Native as well as cultivated and naturalizing. Roadsides, forest edges, thickets, and successional fields.

Understories of forests, woodlands, edges of forests, forested road banks, and rocky slopes often in acidic not deep soils. A very common understory shrub in mesic acidic deciduous forests (sometimes dominated by Quercus rubra).
Shrub and tree swamps, marshes, edges of ponds, and wet thickets. Similar habitat to V. lentago but generally less common, not as weedy, and more restricted to wetlands.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Viburnum dentatum L. var. lucidum Aiton
Habitat: Shrub swamps including rich fens, marshes, forested swamps, wet to mesic successional shrublands, thickets, occasional in mesic deciduous understories, and roadsides. Grows in a large variety of wet to dry habitats. Lately the non-native viburnum leaf beetle (Pyrrhalta viburni) has been completely defoliating this and a few other Viburnum species in parts of New York. It appears that this species might suffer a huge decline.
Stream banks, wet bottomlands, and cool coniferous or coniferous-hardwood forests. Restricted to the coolest parts of NY.

Coniferous, mixed hardwood-coniferous, and hardwood forests; forested stream banks, rocky ledges, and ravine slopes. Very common in the cooler parts of the state including the Adirondacks where it can form dense thickets. These dense thickets may be the result of heavy logging. In other parts of the state it is more restricted to cool forests and ravine slopes and occurs in much thinner patches.

Shrub and tree swamps, marshes, roadside ditches, and wet to mesic successional fields. A common wetland shrub in at least parts of NY it sometimes occur it large shrub thickets mixed with other shrubs including V. dentatum var. lucidum and Cornus spp. It does best in wet soils but also grows in mesic or seasonally flooded areas.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Viburnum opulus L. var. americanum Aiton
Habitat: Shrub and tree swamps (including rich fens), wet thickets, and marshes. Some introgression may be going on with var. opulus.

Dry-mesic forests, thickets, successional shrub thickets, and successional fields. Mostly in thin dry soils. Viburnum prunifolium is mostly restricted to southeastern NY. In some areas that occurs in NY it is probably not native.

Dry to dry-mesic forests, bluffs, woodlands, and rocky summits mostly in calcareous or mineral rich thin soils. It generally occurs in small to large size patches which can be quite dense; the larger patches occurring in less shaded sites. Often it is not distributed throughout a site but has a more limited local distribution.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Vicia americana Muhl. ex Willd. var. americana
Habitat: Edges of forests, woodlands, bluffs, thickets, and roadsides. In dry to mesic soils.
Edges of forests, thin forests, woodlands, shale and fine talus slopes, and road banks. Not very weedy with us but often occurring in open habitats.
Mesic hardwood and mixed coniferous-hardwood forests, mesic to wet-mesic forest openings, hummocks in swamps, swamp margins, and forested dirt roadsides.
Hardwood forests in deep rich mesic soils often in valley bottoms or lower slopes.
Marshes, low areas in swamps, forested seeps, edges of small streams, and rarely in more mesic habitats.
Mesic forests, forest edges, wet forests, and high terraces of floodplains of small streams.
Edges of streams, pond and lake margins, and wet thickets. In non-shaded wetlands on saturated (at least seasonally) sandy soils with adjacent vegetation sparse.
Margins of ponds and lakes, stream edges, acidic to alkaline peatlands, and wet thickets in perennially saturated mucky soils often growing in mosses.
Dry-mesic hardwood forests and forest edges on middle to upper slopes and tops of hills in acidic soils.
Mesic to dry-mesic hardwood forests generally in acidic coarse grained soils. Generally in lower pH, drier, coarser, and thinner soils than Viola pubescens var. scabriuscula.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Viola pubescens Aiton var. scabriuscula Torr. & A. Gray
Habitat: Mesic to wet-mesic hardwood forests often in valley bottoms or mid to low slopes. Generally in higher pH, more mesic, finer, and deeper soils than Viola pubescens var. pubescens.
Cool calcareous rocky hardwood to coniferous forests and sometimes associated with rock outcrops. Generally in mesic soils but occasionally in wetter habitats.
Hardwood forests in rich well drained mesic soils.
Cool rich mesic forests especially on high terrace floodplains of small streams; and edges of dirt roads and paths through forests.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Viola sagittata Aiton var. ovata (Nutt.) Torr. & A. Gray
Habitat: Successional fields, utility rights-of-way, gravel and sand mines, roadsides, woodlands, forest openings, thin canopied forests, and disturbed areas in forests in thin well drained dry to dry-mesic to occasionally mesic soils.
Rich cool calcareous mesic hardwood forests. Populations are often small and isolated. Often found at the very base of trees.
Mesic to dry-mesic hardwood forests and forest edges. Generally on mid to upper slopes or tops of hills. In drier less rich habitats than Viola sororia.

Best developed in valley bottoms and lower slopes of mesic to wet-mesic hardwood forests and forest edges; also in mesic forests, forest edges, lawns, disturbed soils, roadsides, thickets, and waste places. Widespread and very common.
Hardwood forests, forest edges and openings, thickets, and disturbed sites.
Thickets, forest edges, and forests (often young forests or forests with a history of disturbance).
Hardwood forests, forest edges and openings, thickets, disturbed sites, and rocky open slopes.
Quiet water of ponds, lakes, and marshes. Often growing in mixed populations with other Wolffia species.
Quiet water of ponds, lakes, and marshes. Often growing in mixed populations with other Wolffia species.
Dry ledges, bluffs, and cliffs, mostly in warm exposed habitats on various rock types.
Wet to seasonally seepy cliffs, ledges, and shale or fine talus slopes. Very occasionally in soil. Predominately on calcareous substrates, but not limited to these.

Scientific_Name_With_Authors: Xanthium strumarium L. var. canadense (Mill.) Torr. & A. Gray

Habitat: Wet thickets, low and floodplain mesic forests, streamside thickets, thin soils over limestone and calcareous bedrock, and other calcareous habitats both wet and dry.

Thin dry open forests, edges of forests, clearings with low non aggressive herbaceous vegetation, rims of larger ravines, and non weedy roadsides and paths.  It prefers dry sites that have a thin canopy.  Dense canopies may cause this species to disappear. This species has similar habitat preferences to Taenidia integerrima although Z. aptera does equally well in non calcareous sites.
Floodplain and rich mesic forests, and thickets in bottomlands.  This species does well on floodplain terraces and in deep alluvial soils.
